query:
Write a Related Works section for an academic paper given the paper's abstract. Here is the paper abstract:
With the growing abundance of repositories containing tabular data,
discovering relevant tables for in-depth analysis remains a challenging task.
Existing table discovery methods primarily retrieve desired tables based on a
query table or several vague keywords, leaving users to manually filter large
result sets. To address this limitation, we propose a new task: NL-conditional
table discovery (nlcTD), where users combine a query table with natural
language (NL) requirements to refine search results. To advance research in
this area, we present nlcTables, a comprehensive benchmark dataset comprising
627 diverse queries spanning NL-only, union, join, and fuzzy conditions, 22,080
candidate tables, and 21,200 relevance annotations. Our evaluation of six
state-of-the-art table discovery methods on nlcTables reveals substantial
performance gaps, highlighting the need for advanced techniques to tackle this
challenging nlcTD scenario. The dataset, construction framework, and baseline
implementations are publicly available at
https://github.com/SuDIS-ZJU/nlcTables to foster future research.

nuggets.text: Keyword-based table search retrieves tables using user-provided keywords
Query-table-based search finds tables relevant to a given query table
Existing methods support only keywords or query tables as input
No prior dataset supports NL-conditional table discovery
Existing datasets focus on keyword or query-table-based retrieval
Existing datasets lack ternary NL condition, query table, candidate table relationships
Existing datasets are small or lack diversity for NL-conditional tasks
nlcTables introduces NL-conditional table discovery benchmark
nlcTables supports NL-only, union, join, and fuzzy conditions
Six state-of-the-art methods show performance gaps on nlcTables
nlcTables enables robust, scalable evaluation for real-world NL-conditional discovery
Keyword-based methods treat tables as plain text or token sequences
Table union search retrieves union-compatible tables for merging
Table join search retrieves tables joinable at a specified column
Early union search used probabilistic models for column similarity
Recent union search uses table representation learning for column embeddings
Join search evolved from set similarity to semantic embedding approaches
WikiTables supports only keyword-based search
TUS and Santos datasets focus on table union search
LakeBench generates union and join datasets from OpenData and WebTable
nlcTables contains 627 queries, 22,080 candidate tables, 21,200 annotations
